title: 106_s1704
content: The "Access to High Standards Act" may be cited as the short title of this legislation. The findings and purposes of the Act are outlined in Section 2. Congress finds that many students lack academic preparation in secondary school, leading to limited job opportunities, high college dropout rates, and the need for remediation in college. There is a consensus that raising academic standards and expectations is crucial for improving public education, with a focus on modeling standards after advanced placement courses. Establishing high academic expectations and concrete results are key to improving public education. Many education leaders and almost half of all States endorse modeling academic standards after advanced placement courses. These programs offer 30 college-level courses, are present in almost 60% of secondary schools, and serve over 1,000,000 students, with 80% attending public schools, 55% being females, and 30% being minorities. "Advanced placement programs offer 30 college-level courses in almost 60% of secondary schools, reaching over 1,000,000 students. Test scores are accepted for college credit at over 3,000 colleges and universities, including those in Germany, France, Austria, Canada, and the United Kingdom. 24 States fund programs to increase participation in advanced placement, with 19 States providing funds for teachers." "24 States fund programs to increase participation in advanced placement, including funds for teacher professional development, test fees, and granting academic credit for test scores." The Act highlights that 4 States require public universities to grant academic credit for scores of 3 or better on advanced placement tests. State programs have raised academic standards, increased enrollment, achievement, and minority participation in advanced placement programs. The purposes of this Act are outlined. The Act aims to encourage more students to take advanced placement exams and highlights the benefits of these programs for students, including important skills acquisition for employers. The Act aims to encourage students to take advanced placement exams annually to demonstrate their achievements and support State and local efforts to raise academic standards. Benefits include improved SAT scores, better grades in secondary school and college, and acquisition of important skills for employers. The Act aims to increase student participation and success in advanced placement programs, improve academic standards, and broaden the availability of these programs in schools. The Act aims to increase access to advanced placement programs for low-income and disadvantaged students, diversify student participation, and demonstrate success in larger student groups. The Act aims to increase access to advanced placement programs for low-income and disadvantaged students, diversify student participation, and increase the numbers of students receiving advanced placement test scores for college credit. SEC. 3. ADVANCED PLACEMENT PROGRAM GRANTS. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities on a competitive basis to carry out authorized activities for a period of 3 years with annual payments. Eligible entities are defined in this section. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities on a competitive basis for a 3-year period with annual payments. Eligible entities are defined as State or local educational agencies. Priority will be given to entities demonstrating a need for advanced placement incentive programs and involvement of business and community organizations. Priority will be given to eligible entities demonstrating a pervasive need for access to advanced placement programs, involvement of business and community organizations, availability of matching funds, focus on core academic areas, and development or expansion of advanced placement programs. Priority will be given to eligible entities with a focus on developing or expanding advanced placement programs in core academic areas like English, mathematics, and science, targeting schools with a high concentration of low-income students. An eligible entity may use grant funds to expand access for low-income individuals to advanced placement programs through teacher training, pre-advanced placement course development, and curriculum coordination. The advanced placement incentive programs involve teacher training, pre-advanced placement course development, curriculum coordination, curriculum development, books and supplies, and activities to expand access to advanced placement for low-income individuals. Eligible entities must submit an application to the Secretary for a grant. The advanced placement incentive programs aim to increase participation in AP courses, especially for low-income students. Eligible entities must apply for a grant by submitting required information to the Secretary. Data on the number of students taking AP courses must be reported annually. The eligible entity receiving a grant must report annually to the Secretary on the number of students taking advanced placement courses, the number of tests taken, test scores, and demographic information of students disaggregated by various factors. The Secretary must compile and report demographic information on individuals taking advanced placement courses, disaggregated by race, ethnicity, sex, English proficiency, and socioeconomic status to Congress. $25,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for the following 4 years. SEC. 4. ON-LINE ADVANCED PLACEMENT COURSES. The Secretary will award grants to local educational agencies to provide students with online advanced placement courses. Agencies can contract with organizations for course delivery and support services. Priority will be given to agencies serving low-income or rural students. The Secretary will award grants to local educational agencies to provide online advanced placement courses. Priority will be given to agencies serving low-income or rural students who would not have access to online courses without assistance. Grant funds can be used to purchase curriculum, train teachers, or buy course materials. Grant funds provided under this section can be used to purchase online curriculum, train teachers on its use, or buy course materials. Local educational agencies must submit an application to the Secretary to receive a grant. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for the following 4 years. SEC. 5. ADDITIONAL PRIORITIES FOR ADVANCED PLACEMENT. Institutions of higher education receiving Federal funds must provide information on academic credit for advanced placement test scores to secondary school counselors. They are required to standardize the dissemination of this information within 4 years of the enactment of the Act. Institutions of higher education must provide information on advanced placement test scores to secondary school counselors and standardize the dissemination of this information within 4 years of the Act's enactment. The Act defines key terms related to advanced placement programs, including "advanced placement incentive program" and "advanced placement test" administered by the College Board or approved by the Secretary. It also defines "high concentration of low-income students" in educational agencies or schools. The term "high concentration of low-income students" refers to an agency or school serving a student population where 40 percent or more are from families with incomes below the poverty level. The term "low-income individual" is defined as someone who is academically prepared to take an advanced placement test, as determined by a school teacher or advanced placement coordinator. The term "institution of higher education" is defined as per the Higher Education Act of 1965. The terms "local educational agency", "secondary school", and "State educational agency" have specific meanings as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. The terms "local educational agency", "secondary school", and "State educational agency" are defined in section 14101 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education. The term "State" includes the several States of the United States, the District of Columbia, and other territories. The term "State" refers to each of the several States of the United States, the District of Columbia, and various territories including Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, and others.
